\doxysubsubsection{Detailed Description}
Bandstop with Q factor\+: the higher the Q factor the more narrow is the notch. However, a narrow notch has a long impulse response ( = ringing) and numerical problems might prevent perfect damping. Practical values of the Q factor are about Q = 10 to 20. In terms of the design the Q factor defines the radius of the poles as r = exp(-\/ pi\texorpdfstring{$\ast$}{*}(center\+Frequency/sample\+Rate)/q\+\_\+factor) whereas the angles of the poles/zeros define the bandstop frequency. The higher Q the closer r moves towards the unit circle.
